P.title: When the next referendum is held on Scotland's Union with the United Kingdom, will Scotland vote to leave?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question applies to the next held referendum, whenever it is held.
It must be a referendum that has an option to leave the union with England. It resolves positively if that option receives the most votes, and negatively otherwise.
In case no referendum is held before 2050, the question resolves ambiguously

para_P.title: In the upcoming referendum on Scotland's Union with the United Kingdom, will Scotland choose to secede?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question pertains to the next referendum, regardless of when it occurs.
The referendum must include an option for Scotland to secede from the union with England. It will resolve affirmatively if the secession option receives the majority of votes, and negatively if it does not.
If no referendum takes place before 2050, the question will resolve as ambiguous.

P.title: When the next referendum is held on Scotland's Union with the United Kingdom, will Scotland vote to leave?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question applies to the next held referendum, whenever it is held.
It must be a referendum that has an option to leave the union with England. It resolves positively if that option receives the most votes, and negatively otherwise.
In case no referendum is held before 2050, the question resolves ambiguously

metadata.background_info:
There is an active question on "Will Scotland leave the United Kingdom before 2025?" however this concerns both the question of when the referendum will be held and how long it would take to implement a leave result. This question is only about the referendum result.
Scotland is a country that's part of the United Kingdom, which also comprises England, Wales, and Northern Ireland (and some overseas dependencies). Scotland has however been increasingly considering leaving the union over the last decades, with one referendum being held in 2014 that resulted in a stay vote (55.3%). However, there is talk of another referendum following the UK's decision to leave the EU (Brexit). Opinion polling for Scottish independence can be found on Wikipedia, though there is currently no planned referendum.

P.title: Will the US set a new annual GDP growth rate record high before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Real GDP Annual Growth Rate in the United States averaged 3.3% from 1930 until 2017, reaching an all time high of 8.7% in 1950 and a record low of -3.90% in the second quarter of 2009.
This question asks: In any year before Q1 2030, will the US record real GDP annual growth rate of greater than 8.7%, beating the record set in 1950?
For the purpose of this question, we shall refer to Real GDP in terms of percent change from preceding year, as provided by the Bureau of Economic Analysis, or other reputable sources of economic data.
Edit: (22 Feb 2019), the question now resolves positively if real GDP in terms of percent change from preceding year exceeds 8.7% instead of resolving positively if annualised quarterly real GDP growth exceeds 13.4%.

para_P.title: Will the United States achieve a new peak in annual GDP growth rate before 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
From 1930 to 2017, the Real GDP Annual Growth Rate in the United States averaged 3.3%, with a peak of 8.7% in 1950 and a low of -3.90% in Q2 2009.
This question asks: Will the US surpass the 8.7% real GDP annual growth rate record set in 1950 in any year before Q1 2030?
For this question, Real GDP is defined as the percent change from the previous year, as reported by the Bureau of Economic Analysis or other credible economic data sources.
Edit: (22 Feb 2019), the question now resolves positively if the real GDP percent change from the previous year exceeds 8.7%, instead of resolving positively if the annualized quarterly real GDP growth exceeds 13.4%.

P.title: Will the US set a new annual GDP growth rate record high before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Real GDP Annual Growth Rate in the United States averaged 3.3% from 1930 until 2017, reaching an all time high of 8.7% in 1950 and a record low of -3.90% in the second quarter of 2009.
This question asks: In any year before Q1 2030, will the US record real GDP annual growth rate of greater than 8.7%, beating the record set in 1950?
For the purpose of this question, we shall refer to Real GDP in terms of percent change from preceding year, as provided by the Bureau of Economic Analysis, or other reputable sources of economic data.
Edit: (22 Feb 2019), the question now resolves positively if real GDP in terms of percent change from preceding year exceeds 8.7% instead of resolving positively if annualised quarterly real GDP growth exceeds 13.4%.

P.title: Does P = NP?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
If no award is given by the Clay Institute (between January 1, 2000 to January 1, 2100) for a proof or disproof of P = NP, this question will resolve ambiguously. The question will resolve ambiguously also if the problem is proven to not have a solution either way, e.g. if the problem will turn out to be unprovable or undecidable. If resolution is positive, the close date will be set retroactively to the date of complete initial publication (in journal or preprint form) of the proof, plus one year (or one day before the date of announcement of the prize, if that comes earlier.)
As some background, Gerhard J. Woeginger maintains a list of claimed proofs of the problem. As of 2018, the list contains 62 purported proofs of P = NP, 50 of P ≠ NP, 2 proofs the problem is unprovable, and one proof that it is undecidable. William I. Gasarch asked 100 various theorists the question whether P = NP. The result are as follows:
61 thought P≠NP.
9 thought P=NP.
4 thought that it is independent.
3 just stated that it is NOT independent of Primitive Recursive Arithmetic.
1 said it would depend on the model.
22 offered no opinion

para_P.title: Is P equal to NP?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
If the Clay Institute does not award a prize (between January 1, 2000, and January 1, 2100) for proving or disproving P = NP, this question will be marked as ambiguous. The question will also be marked as ambiguous if it is shown that the problem cannot be solved either way, such as if it is found to be unprovable or undecidable. If resolved positively, the close date will be set retroactively to the date of the initial complete publication (in journal or preprint form) of the proof, plus one year (or one day before the prize announcement date, if that comes earlier).
For context, Gerhard J. Woeginger keeps a list of claimed proofs of the problem. As of 2018, the list includes 62 claimed proofs of P = NP, 50 of P ≠ NP, 2 proofs that the problem is unprovable, and one proof that it is undecidable. William I. Gasarch surveyed 100 different theorists on whether P = NP. The results were:
61 believed P≠NP.
9 believed P=NP.
4 believed it is independent.
3 stated that it is NOT independent of Primitive Recursive Arithmetic.
1 said it would depend on the model.
22 had no opinion

P.title: Does P = NP?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
If no award is given by the Clay Institute (between January 1, 2000 to January 1, 2100) for a proof or disproof of P = NP, this question will resolve ambiguously. The question will resolve ambiguously also if the problem is proven to not have a solution either way, e.g. if the problem will turn out to be unprovable or undecidable. If resolution is positive, the close date will be set retroactively to the date of complete initial publication (in journal or preprint form) of the proof, plus one year (or one day before the date of announcement of the prize, if that comes earlier.)
As some background, Gerhard J. Woeginger maintains a list of claimed proofs of the problem. As of 2018, the list contains 62 purported proofs of P = NP, 50 of P ≠ NP, 2 proofs the problem is unprovable, and one proof that it is undecidable. William I. Gasarch asked 100 various theorists the question whether P = NP. The result are as follows:
61 thought P≠NP.
9 thought P=NP.
4 thought that it is independent.
3 just stated that it is NOT independent of Primitive Recursive Arithmetic.
1 said it would depend on the model.
22 offered no opinion

metadata.background_info:
P vs. NP is one of the most famous and important problems in computer science. Informally: if the solution to a problem is easy to check for correctness, must the problem also be easy to solve? Aside from being an important problem in computational theory, a proof either way would have profound implications for mathematics, cryptography, algorithm research, artificial intelligence, game theory, multimedia processing, philosophy, economics and many other fields. The problem was included in the Millennium Prize Problems list published by Clay Mathematics Institute, the solutions to which will be awarded 1 million $ prize.
A good introduction to the problem is YouTube video "P vs. NP and the Computational Complexity Zoo" by hackerdashery.

P.title: Will MIRI employ researchers in 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if, on 2030-01-01 MIRI exists and employs researchers to work on AI Safety.
For the purpose of this question AI Safety is broadly defined as any technical work, at any level of abstraction, focused on the alignment of AI systems, existing or hypothetical, with some broad notion of human interests.
Research is here defined as involving developing novel ideas and insights broadly in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields (such as computer science or mathematics) at the time. Currently, blog posts alone wouldn't count for resolution as this does not currently conform to the standard format of academic publications. For the purpose of this question, such research need not be published nor made publicly available. In case it is unclear whether this work is done, a moderator may contact MIRI to confirm.
If MIRI changes its name, the new organization is used for resolution as if there was no name change. If MIRI merges into another organization, the resulting merged organization is used for resolution. In case of a dispute over the question resolution criteria, if at least one moderator and admin concur that the resolution criteria must change, then it shall. In case of a dispute between admins, a vote in the comment section will determine the correct resolution.
In case MIRI's research is circulated internally only, the requirement that the work need to be "developed in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields" will not apply.

para_P.title: Will MIRI have researchers on staff in 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves affirmatively if, on 2030-01-01, MIRI is operational and employs researchers dedicated to AI Safety.
For the purpose of this question, AI Safety is broadly defined as any technical work, at any level of abstraction, focused on aligning AI systems, whether existing or hypothetical, with a broad notion of human interests.
Research is defined here as the development of novel ideas and insights, generally in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields (such as computer science or mathematics) at the time. Currently, blog posts alone would not qualify for resolution as they do not conform to the standard format of academic publications. For the purpose of this question, such research need not be published or made publicly available. If it is unclear whether this work is being done, a moderator may contact MIRI for confirmation.
If MIRI changes its name, the new organization will be used for resolution as if there was no name change. If MIRI merges with another organization, the resulting merged organization will be used for resolution. In case of a dispute over the question resolution criteria, if at least one moderator and admin agree that the resolution criteria must change, then it shall. In case of a dispute between admins, a vote in the comment section will determine the correct resolution.
If MIRI's research is circulated internally only, the requirement that the work be "developed in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields" will not apply.

P.title: Will MIRI employ researchers in 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if, on 2030-01-01 MIRI exists and employs researchers to work on AI Safety.
For the purpose of this question AI Safety is broadly defined as any technical work, at any level of abstraction, focused on the alignment of AI systems, existing or hypothetical, with some broad notion of human interests.
Research is here defined as involving developing novel ideas and insights broadly in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields (such as computer science or mathematics) at the time. Currently, blog posts alone wouldn't count for resolution as this does not currently conform to the standard format of academic publications. For the purpose of this question, such research need not be published nor made publicly available. In case it is unclear whether this work is done, a moderator may contact MIRI to confirm.
If MIRI changes its name, the new organization is used for resolution as if there was no name change. If MIRI merges into another organization, the resulting merged organization is used for resolution. In case of a dispute over the question resolution criteria, if at least one moderator and admin concur that the resolution criteria must change, then it shall. In case of a dispute between admins, a vote in the comment section will determine the correct resolution.
In case MIRI's research is circulated internally only, the requirement that the work need to be "developed in the standard format of academic publications in relevant fields" will not apply.

metadata.background_info:
The Machine Intelligence Research Institute (MIRI) is a non-profit research institute focused since 2005 on identifying and managing potential existential risks from artificial general intelligence.
According to its website:
MIRI’s mission is to ensure that the creation of smarter-than-human intelligence has a positive impact. We aim to make advanced intelligent systems behave as we intend even in the absence of immediate human supervision.
Recently, MIRI has shared that it has made limited progress on a research direction it has been pursuing:
At the same time, 2020 saw limited progress in the research MIRI’s leadership had previously been most excited about: the new research directions we started in 2017. Given our slow progress to date, we are considering a number of possible changes to our strategy, and MIRI’s research leadership is shifting much of their focus toward searching for more promising paths.

P.title: Who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Donald Trump)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as No. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.
For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.
Fine Print
If there is no Republican National Convention convened in the year 2024, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.
Note: in the previous versions of this question, Donald Trump's question originally asked "If Trump is not sworn in as President in 2021, will he become the Republican nominee for President in 2024?"; please bear this in mind when interpreting the forecast history.

para_P.title: Will Donald Trump be chosen as the Republican candidate for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the candidate listed below who is chosen by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as No. This question is not limited to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.
For this question, it does not matter who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.
Fine Print
If there is no Republican National Convention held in the year 2024, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.
Note: in previous versions of this question, Donald Trump's question originally asked "If Trump is not sworn in as President in 2021, will he become the Republican nominee for President in 2024?"; please keep this in mind when interpreting the forecast history.

P.title: Who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Donald Trump)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as No. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.
For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.
Fine Print
If there is no Republican National Convention convened in the year 2024, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.
Note: in the previous versions of this question, Donald Trump's question originally asked "If Trump is not sworn in as President in 2021, will he become the Republican nominee for President in 2024?"; please bear this in mind when interpreting the forecast history.

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, saying at a rally in March 2022, "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before". Early polling for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.
Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of June 2022), though Fox News producers have called him "the future of the Republican Party". DeSantis is a frequent second-place favorite in polling behind Trump.
Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; in April 2022, when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

P.title: Will NASA return a sample of material from the surface of Mars to Earth before SpaceX Starship lands on Mars?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The resolution of this question depends on the relative timing of two events:
1) A mission substantially (>30%) or wholly funded by NASA successfully returns a sample from the surface of Mars to Earth.
2) A rocket build by SpaceX designated as "Starship" or clearly designated as a successor to Starship successfully lands on Mars.
The question will resolve positive if event 1) happens before event 2).
The question will resolve negatively if event 2) happens before event 1).
If neither of these events happens before the closing date (2035) the question will resolve ambiguously.
Note that the following series of events would result in a negative resolution: SpaceX builds a Starship rocket which is purchased by NASA. That rocket lands on Mars successfully. That rocket returns to Earth with samples from Mars in it. Because the SpaceX Starship landed on Mars before the NASA mission returned samples to Earth, the question resolves negative.
Similarly, the following sequence of events would resolve positive: NASA contracts a Falcon Heavy from SpaceX for one of its missions. That mission successfully returns samples to Earth before Starship lands on earth.
It is also worth noting that if both NASA and SpaceX hew to their currently claimed timelines, Starship will land on Mars in 2026, 4 years before a sample return mission is completed in 2030

para_P.title: Will a NASA mission bring back a sample from Mars to Earth before SpaceX's Starship touches down on Mars?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The resolution of this question depends on the relative timing of two events:
1) A mission substantially (>30%) or wholly funded by NASA successfully returns a sample from the surface of Mars to Earth.
2) A rocket built by SpaceX designated as "Starship" or clearly designated as a successor to Starship successfully lands on Mars.
The question will resolve positively if event 1) happens before event 2).
The question will resolve negatively if event 2) happens before event 1).
If neither of these events happens before the closing date (2035), the question will resolve ambiguously.
Note that the following series of events would result in a negative resolution: SpaceX builds a Starship rocket which is purchased by NASA. That rocket lands on Mars successfully. That rocket returns to Earth with samples from Mars in it. Because the SpaceX Starship landed on Mars before the NASA mission returned samples to Earth, the question resolves negatively.
Similarly, the following sequence of events would resolve positively: NASA contracts a Falcon Heavy from SpaceX for one of its missions. That mission successfully returns samples to Earth before Starship lands on Mars.
It is also worth noting that if both NASA and SpaceX adhere to their currently claimed timelines, Starship will land on Mars in 2026, 4 years before a sample return mission is completed in 2030.

P.title: Will NASA return a sample of material from the surface of Mars to Earth before SpaceX Starship lands on Mars?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The resolution of this question depends on the relative timing of two events:
1) A mission substantially (>30%) or wholly funded by NASA successfully returns a sample from the surface of Mars to Earth.
2) A rocket build by SpaceX designated as "Starship" or clearly designated as a successor to Starship successfully lands on Mars.
The question will resolve positive if event 1) happens before event 2).

If neither of these events happens before the closing date (2035) the question will resolve ambiguously.
Note that the following series of events would result in a negative resolution: SpaceX builds a Starship rocket which is purchased by NASA. That rocket lands on Mars successfully. That rocket returns to Earth with samples from Mars in it. Because the SpaceX Starship landed on Mars before the NASA mission returned samples to Earth, the question resolves negative.

It is also worth noting that if both NASA and SpaceX hew to their currently claimed timelines, Starship will land on Mars in 2026, 4 years before a sample return mission is completed in 2030

metadata.background_info:
NASA's first successful lander was the Viking 1 lander in 1975. Since then, NASA's missions to Mars have increased in number and complexity. While NASA's stated ultimate objective is bringing humans to Mars and back, an intermediate goal is that of sample-return, bringing a sample of material from the surface of Mars back to Earth. Given a 2-year trip each way, a mission tenatively planned to launch in 2026 would return samples to Earth around 2030.
SpaceX has been working on its own "Mars" program, the Starship. Elon Musk has claimed that the Starship may launch for Mars as soon as 2024. Such a mission would land on Mars in 2026.

P.title: Will Ray Kurzweil be proven right?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Ray Kurzweil is an author, computer scientist, inventor and futurist. He is best known for making what many consider to be extremely optimistic prediction about the future of technology that involve exponential growth leading up to technological singularity, which Kurzweil predicts will happen circa. 2045. A list of Kurzweil's predictions can be found here.
Will Ray Kurzweil be proven generally right in his predictions?
Note that the question refers to Kurzweil's predictions as of the time of the the writing of the question. Given that 'generally right' is hard to define, the question shall use consensus forming to create its own answer.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is > 80%, then the questions resolves positive.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is < 20%, then the questions resolves negative.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is ≥ 20% and ≤80%, then a member of Metaculus staff shall decide resolution.
To help reduce the vagueness of the question, Metaculus may, at its discretion, periodically survey the perceived correctness of Kurzweil's prediction, per a fixed methodology similar to that employed in this report, but with a modification to survey and weight by importance of the prediction.

para_P.title: Will Ray Kurzweil's predictions be validated?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Ray Kurzweil is an author, computer scientist, inventor, and futurist. He is renowned for making what many consider to be highly optimistic forecasts about the future of technology, involving exponential growth leading to a technological singularity, which Kurzweil anticipates around 2045. A compilation of Kurzweil's predictions can be found here.
Will Ray Kurzweil's predictions be generally validated?
Note that the question pertains to Kurzweil's predictions as of the time of the writing of the question. Given that 'generally validated' is difficult to define, the question will use consensus forming to determine its answer.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is > 80%, then the question resolves positively.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is < 20%, then the question resolves negatively.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is ≥ 20% and ≤80%, then a member of Metaculus staff will decide the resolution.
To help mitigate the vagueness of the question, Metaculus may, at its discretion, periodically survey the perceived accuracy of Kurzweil's predictions, using a fixed methodology similar to that employed in this report, but with a modification to survey and weight by the importance of the prediction.

Will Ray Kurzweil be proven generally right in his predictions?
Note that the question refers to Kurzweil's predictions as of the time of the the writing of the question. Given that 'generally right' is hard to define, the question shall use consensus forming to create its own answer.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is > 80%, then the questions resolves positive.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is < 20%, then the questions resolves negative.
If the community prediction at the time of closing is ≥ 20% and ≤80%, then a member of Metaculus staff shall decide resolution.
To help reduce the vagueness of the question, Metaculus may, at its discretion, periodically survey the perceived correctness of Kurzweil's prediction, per a fixed methodology similar to that employed in this report, but with a modification to survey and weight by importance of the prediction.

P.title: Will Sam Bankman-Fried have donated $1bn 2021 USD to charitable causes before 2031?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This resolves positive if, by year end 2030, there is a public record of donations by SBF or grants by a grantmaking organisation of which he is the primary funder (see fine print) which total over $1bn in 2021 USD.
Donations to political campaigns or to an unallocated DAF or foundation which is under his control should not be counted for this question. Donations by the FTX Foundation should not count either, except if the assets in question are donated to the Foundation by Bankman-Fried himself and regranted by the question deadline. Donations to foundations or trusts which he does not control, but is a beneficiary of; or that exist wholly, primarily, or partly for the benefit of his friends and family should also be excluded.
Fine Print
If Bankman-Fried is the primary funder of a grantmaking organisation but not the sole funder, the amount granted for the purpose of this qustion should be the best available estimate of what fraction of funding he provides, multiplied by the amount granted.
If he funds such an organisation with a spouse (i.e. similar to Bill and Melinda Gates' Foundation, or Dustin Moskovitz and Cari Tuna's Good Ventures), then their combined contribution should be counted for the purpose of this question.
If some combination of the above options sums to $1bn, without double counting the donation and regranting of the same funds, then this should resolve positively.

para_P.title: Will Sam Bankman-Fried have contributed $1 billion (2021 USD) to charitable causes by the end of 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will be answered affirmatively if, by the end of 2030, there is verifiable evidence of donations made by SBF or grants issued by a grantmaking entity primarily funded by him (see details below) that total over $1 billion in 2021 USD.
Contributions to political campaigns or to an unallocated Donor-Advised Fund (DAF) or foundation under his control are excluded. Donations by the FTX Foundation are also excluded unless the assets were donated to the Foundation by Bankman-Fried himself and regranted by the deadline. Contributions to foundations or trusts that he does not control but benefits from, or that exist mainly for the benefit of his friends and family, are also excluded.
Details
If Bankman-Fried is the primary but not sole funder of a grantmaking entity, the amount considered for this question will be the best available estimate of his funding proportion, multiplied by the total grants issued.
If he co-funds such an entity with a spouse (similar to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation or Dustin Moskovitz and Cari Tuna's Good Ventures), their combined contributions will be counted.
If the sum of these contributions reaches $1 billion, without double-counting any regranted funds, the question will be resolved affirmatively.

P.title: Will Sam Bankman-Fried have donated $1bn 2021 USD to charitable causes before 2031?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This resolves positive if, by year end 2030, there is a public record of donations by SBF or grants by a grantmaking organisation of which he is the primary funder (see fine print) which total over $1bn in 2021 USD.
Donations to political campaigns or to an unallocated DAF or foundation which is under his control should not be counted for this question. Donations by the FTX Foundation should not count either, except if the assets in question are donated to the Foundation by Bankman-Fried himself and regranted by the question deadline. Donations to foundations or trusts which he does not control, but is a beneficiary of; or that exist wholly, primarily, or partly for the benefit of his friends and family should also be excluded.
Fine Print
If Bankman-Fried is the primary funder of a grantmaking organisation but not the sole funder, the amount granted for the purpose of this qustion should be the best available estimate of what fraction of funding he provides, multiplied by the amount granted.
If he funds such an organisation with a spouse (i.e. similar to Bill and Melinda Gates' Foundation, or Dustin Moskovitz and Cari Tuna's Good Ventures), then their combined contribution should be counted for the purpose of this question.
If some combination of the above options sums to $1bn, without double counting the donation and regranting of the same funds, then this should resolve positively.

metadata.background_info:
Sam Bankman-Fried is a US cryptocurrency billionaire, with an estimated net worth of $16.2 billion in August 2021, according to Forbes.
Bankman-Fried is a long time advocate for Effective Altruism, and has on numerous occasions stated his intention to give most of his fortune away.
This question asks if he will manage to grant over $1bn 2021 USD before 2031.

P.title: Will smoking and sex be less prevalent in the United States in 2050 than in 2021?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys of US adults in the year 2050 report that the share of adults who have smoked in the past week and the share of adults who have had sex in the past week were both lower than in the year 2021. Comparisons between 2050 and 2021 must be of similar methodology (see fine print) to count towards resolution. If no comparable surveys can be found for both smoking and sex by the resolution date of December 31, 2054, this question will resolve as Ambiguous. This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys would result in positive resolution, conflicting surveys will be considered irrelevant.
Fine Print
Regarding similar methodology, if a survey in 2021 includes e-cigarettes and a survey from 2050 does not the surveys would not be considered to have similar methodology. However, different methodologies can still be acceptable if it can be logically deduced that the surveys provide evidence toward resolution. For example, if a survey in 2021 asked whether respondents had sex in the past year and 25% answered no, and a survey in 2050 asked if respondents had sex in the past five years and 40% answered no, it can be deduced that a larger share of adults in 2050 had not had sex in the past year than in 2021 because the five year period would include the past year.

para_P.title: Will the rates of smoking and sexual activity be lower in the United States in 2050 compared to 2021?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys of US adults in the year 2050 indicate that the percentage of adults who have smoked in the past week and the percentage of adults who have engaged in sexual activity in the past week are both lower than those in the year 2021. Comparisons between 2050 and 2021 must use similar methodologies (see fine print) to be considered valid for resolution. If no comparable surveys are available for both smoking and sexual activity by the resolution date of December 31, 2054, this question will resolve as Ambiguous. This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys support a positive resolution, and conflicting surveys will be disregarded.
Fine Print
Regarding similar methodologies, if a survey in 2021 includes e-cigarettes and a survey from 2050 does not, the surveys would not be considered methodologically similar. However, different methodologies can still be acceptable if it can be logically deduced that the surveys provide evidence toward resolution. For example, if a survey in 2021 asked whether respondents had sex in the past year and 25% answered no, and a survey in 2050 asked if respondents had sex in the past five years and 40% answered no, it can be deduced that a larger share of adults in 2050 had not had sex in the past year compared to 2021 because the five-year period would include the past year.

P.title: Will smoking and sex be less prevalent in the United States in 2050 than in 2021?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys of US adults in the year 2050 report that the share of adults who have smoked in the past week and the share of adults who have had sex in the past week were both lower than in the year 2021. Comparisons between 2050 and 2021 must be of similar methodology (see fine print) to count towards resolution. If no comparable surveys can be found for both smoking and sex by the resolution date of December 31, 2054, this question will resolve as Ambiguous. This question will resolve as Yes if any credible surveys would result in positive resolution, conflicting surveys will be considered irrelevant.
Fine Print
Regarding similar methodology, if a survey in 2021 includes e-cigarettes and a survey from 2050 does not the surveys would not be considered to have similar methodology. However, different methodologies can still be acceptable if it can be logically deduced that the surveys provide evidence toward resolution. For example, if a survey in 2021 asked whether respondents had sex in the past year and 25% answered no, and a survey in 2050 asked if respondents had sex in the past five years and 40% answered no, it can be deduced that a larger share of adults in 2050 had not had sex in the past year than in 2021 because the five year period would include the past year.

metadata.background_info:
Neuroscientist and fiction author Erik Hoel wrote the following about social behavior in the year 2050 in a blog post published August 25, 2021
All socially risky behavior is on the decline, and has been in the decade since social media and the introduction of the smart phone. People in 2050 will have less sex, do less drugs, have less affairs, smoke less, and conform more in their opinions.
A survey from Gallup finds that 16% of US adults had smoked a cigarette in the last week in 2021. And an article in the Washington Post reports that 23% of US adults had not had sex in the past year in 2018.

P.title: Will there be a culturally significant development in aging research by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
In 2019, at a speech at the Foresight Institute, biomedical gerontologist Aubrey de Grey stated:
I think we are still 15-20 years away [from effective anti-aging therapies] but the anticipation of the therapy by the general public is coming soon, and it is that anticipation that is going to be the point when the shit really hits the fan. If you think about a situation in which less than five years from now [...] in a period of about a week, half of the developed world is going to shift from an expectation that they will live only slightly longer than their parents did, into an expectation that they're going to live far longer than anyone has ever lived.
If half of the people in the developed world came to believe within a period of a week that effective anti-aging therapies were imminent, this would likely be a culturally significant event, perhaps among the most significant in the 2020's.
This question resolves positively if any of the terms "aging", "ageing", "anti-aging", "anti-ageing", "longevity", "lifespan", "rejuvenation", or "life extension" are mentioned as a direct reference to longevity research* in any of the following media sources produced between January 1st 2020 and January 1st 2030 UTC:
The English Wikipedia's "In the news" section.
or
History.com's summary of events for a year in the 2020's.
or
The transcript for a primary or general presidential election debate in America.
It also resolves positively if:
A longevity researcher receives Time's Person of the Year for their work on defeating aging.
Otherwise, this question resolves negatively on the 1st of January 2030.
In case of positive resolution, this question retroactively closes 1 day before the triggering event.
ETA: 2022-04-08: qualifying primary or general presidential election debates are limited to mainstream debates (i.e., Republican and Democratic primaries + general election debates).
* "longevity research" here means the research comes from a group whose explicit purpose (as defined by their charter, or their about page on their website, or by some official statement made by the organisation which pertains to their research ends) is to slow, halt, or reverse the natural aging process. Examples of research groups which meet this criteria are the SENS Research Foundation and The Sinclair Lab at Harvard.

para_P.title: Will there be a culturally impactful breakthrough in aging research by 2030?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
In 2019, during a speech at the Foresight Institute, biomedical gerontologist Aubrey de Grey mentioned:
I believe we are still 15-20 years away [from effective anti-aging therapies] but the public's anticipation of the therapy is imminent, and it is that anticipation that will be the turning point. Imagine a scenario where in less than five years [...] within a week, half of the developed world shifts from expecting to live only slightly longer than their parents to expecting to live significantly longer than anyone has ever lived.
If within a week, half of the people in the developed world come to believe that effective anti-aging therapies are imminent, this would likely be a culturally impactful event, potentially one of the most significant in the 2020's.
This question resolves affirmatively if any of the terms "aging", "ageing", "anti-aging", "anti-ageing", "longevity", "lifespan", "rejuvenation", or "life extension" are directly referenced in relation to longevity research* in any of the following media sources produced between January 1st 2020 and January 1st 2030 UTC:
The English Wikipedia's "In the news" section.
or
History.com's summary of events for a year in the 2020's.
or
The transcript for a primary or general presidential election debate in America.
It also resolves affirmatively if:
A longevity researcher is named Time's Person of the Year for their work on combating aging.
Otherwise, this question resolves negatively on January 1st, 2030.
In the case of a positive resolution, this question retroactively closes 1 day before the triggering event.
ETA: 2022-04-08: qualifying primary or general presidential election debates are limited to mainstream debates (i.e., Republican and Democratic primaries + general election debates).
* "longevity research" here refers to research conducted by a group whose explicit purpose (as defined by their charter, about page on their website, or an official statement made by the organization regarding their research goals) is to slow, halt, or reverse the natural aging process. Examples of research groups that meet this criterion include the SENS Research Foundation and The Sinclair Lab at Harvard.
